My community is in the midst of a "Bike/Ped Trail Plan" so I've taken the time to read hundreds of these comments. Some noticeable refrains:

---all street bicycles should be equipped with turn signals, headlights and brake lights, and cyclists themselves should be licensed.
---texting while driving should be against the law everywhere
---drivers need to check their mirrors before making right-hand turns
---SUVs have gotten too big if "I swear I couldn't see him" is a frequent excuse, and fewer built-in vehicle distractions should be lawful
---"mixed-use trails" are not realistic, as pedestrians don't want to be paired with cyclists (too dangerous) and cyclists don't want to be paired with pedestrians (too slow.)
---those who say there should be separate street lanes for cars, bikes and pedestrians have an amazing lack of awareness of private property, businesses, street trees, parking lanes, front yards, etc. How wide should streets be to accommodate everyone's transportation choices? Should we just pave the whole world? (you do know I'm kidding, right?)

I could go on and on, but I've come to the conclusion that the best transportation solution is neither cars OR bikes, but light rail. And I hope the digital age will mean more and more employees will be able to work from home, lightening the commuter transportation load everywhere.

In part 1, it was proven that given a set of initial family sizes: $a, b, c… $, the final frog population after combining all of the lakes would be (regardless of the order of combination) something like $a + b + c +… + ab + bc + cb + … + abc + …$ -- all possible product sets of the initial variables. But there is a mathematical shortcut: $a + b + c +… + ab + bc + cb + … + abc + … = (a+1)*(b+1)*(c+1)*… -1.$ In other words, add one to every initial family size, then multiply all of those new numbers together and subtract 1 from the result. Boom! Done. But why?

In short, it’s true because $(a+1)(b+1)= ab + a + b + 1$. Therefore, our desired sum, $ ab + a + b$ is equal to $(a+1)(b+1)-1$. And when we look to combine this new answer with $c$, the next variable, the result is $((a+1)(b+1)-1)+1(c+1)-1$ The $-1$ and $+1$ cancel of course and it simplifies beautifully to: $(a+1)(b+1)(c+1)-1$. One more demonstration , accounting for the next variable, $d$: $((a+1)(b+1)(c+1)-1)+1(d+1)-1 = (a+1)(b+1)(c+1)(d+1)-1 $. Etc. :)

But I’m not a big fan of algebraic simplification tricks that seem to appear from ‘thin air.’ And, to be honest, that’s probably because I’m terrible at finding them! In any case, I tend to rely on geometry instead to bail me out, and in this problem that geometry takes a very compelling form. You might guess it from the application of the $a+b+ab$ operation and from what those “pieces” look like geometrically. Looking at these pieces is how Rafael and I (mainly Rafael in this case) found the algebraic trick. You can figure it out just by playing around with the pieces:

https://sites.google.com/site/applelessgarden/_/rsrc/1411185417944/ppv/a...

This picture illustrates how $(a+1)(b+1)= ab + a + b + 1$. And, regardless, I’m much more OK with geometric simplifications that come out of thin air. ;-)

And this one generalizes beautifully. It’s a little tricky to visualize it for more than 3 variables, but here is the 3 variable case:

https://sites.google.com/site/applelessgarden/_/rsrc/1411185399545/ppv/a...

The pattern continues into however many variables and DIMENSIONS you want. Rafael points out that if you count the number of n-dimensional blocks being used to build this image for any number of variables, you’ll always get a power of 2, and that if you count the number of blocks that measure 1 unit in all dimensions save for k of them, the distribution is the numbers in the nth row of Pascal’s Triangle. In this case, there is 1 1x1x1 cube, 3 rods, 3 sheets, and 1 axbxc block: $1-3-3-1$. Pretty neat, right? :D

https://sites.google.com/site/applelessgarden/_/rsrc/1411186292531/ppv/a...

In response to this amazing vote, Great Britain avoided a catastrophe of being politically & permanently divided and of being severely weakened.    I was surprised with the inadequately assessed risks that the Scots took to pursue this vote.  No independent currency, inevitable major business departures, weak infrastructure, impotent military. In fact, Cameron MUST engage all parties in harmonious communication, and be simultaneously humble and forthright when the moments require these types of  communication.    British people must workout their differences and reach common-ground to survive as a nation and recapture perhaps a competitive advantage of influence that will resonate to help other nations that make-up the community of our world. MPW he most emphatically is not wrong in his first sentence!  Modern science was initiated by considering the wholly quantitative and subtracting the qualitative from the physical world.  Hence the mechanistic philosophy. Hence dualism which gradually gave way to materialism.

It's never too late for truth. True that there was a mind-orientated "dualist" understanding of natural science (natural philosophy) from the beginning; just read Newton's Principia, second edition (1713): active nonmaterial "force" and passive matter in causal interaction.  Not true that one could ever explain nature better without this duality. Natural science itself is still based on the duality of cause and effect, mind and cosmos, body and soul, force and motion, energy and momentum: E/p = c; E/mc = c. Scientists believe in a materialist conception of nature, but mathematical science itself and nature herself reveal a spirit-matter (cause-effect) duality to the impartial observer.

This idea that science and religion have been intrinsically at odds in the past is rejected by the majority of historians.  Normally when science and religion attempt to occupy the same intellectual ground, compromise and consideration have been the flavor of the day.  Up until recently, there hasn't been any of this reaction to science.  Of course recently things have changed, and materialists have been trying to use science as a weapon with which to bludgeon their ideological opponents, so maybe some of it is called for.

I realize I'm a bit late to this party, but I couldn't resist throwing in my meager two cents...

Nagel is utterly wrong in his very first sentence. The subtraction of a consciousness (a deity, generally) from the workings of the natural world, and the substitution of a mechanistic understanding, was not a "limiting step" decided "at the start." It was a gradual, halting process, begun by people who started out with a "mind-oriented" (theistic) understanding of the cosmos, as most humans apparently have always had. Over the centuries, this approach was slowly leached out of "natural philosophy" because the pioneers discovered that it contributed nothing to their discoveries and was in fact misleading - i.e., you could explain nature better without it. That Nagel doesn't know or ignores this basic, central theme of the history of science leads me to wonder why he, or anyone, thinks he is any position to lecture scientists on these matters.

Even more succinct version: Science *tried* the idea of a cosmos with a mind already; it didn't work.
